title: Are manipulative people highly intelligent? - Quora

response.answer_text: Of course not. We are all born manipulative. Toddlers present behaviours that in an adult would be called manipulative. Manipulation is purely a basic reflex. The most you can say is that people who are not manipulative have a flaw called empathy, if you want to see it that way. Manipulating is very simple. You smile and complement a lot when others behave in a way that it is convenient for you, and you get seriously angry when they do something that it is not. Avoid compromise, and never see something from the other´s point of view. It’s really important to constantly play the victim so it seems like it is someone else’s fault. If someone calls you out on your game, you scream and say they are attacking you and being mean. And although you never see things from the other’s perspective, always complain and demand that everyone sees things from your side. There, you have achieved manipulation. Smarter people tend to be less manipulative because they voluntarially contradict their personal bias, and make an effort to look at the bigger picture. The result is that a lot of times, because of this empathy and comprehension they end up finishing last. But if manipulative people are not smart they always think they are the smartest. Certainly we al tend to over rate our own intelligence but manipulators loose sight of reality. Manipulative people always lie a lot, creating the most implausible and pathetic lies, expecting others to believe. Of course, most of the time, others realize they are lying, but no one likes confrontation, so everyone pretends to believe or just ignore. The result is that the manipulators get this feeling that they are some kind of masterminds, and dive head first on their lying rampage. Another common trait for manipulators is never letting anyone pointing their failures, blocking it the most aggressive way. But when something comes up, they’ll easily say “why didn’t you said anything?”. Again, it’s someone else’s fault. Eventually, others get fed up and move away. They will just move on to manipulate someone else, and they keep on moving. At some point, they realize that everyone around them moves away. Even then, they still feed the need to blame others, so it’s common for them to start making vague accusations to no one in particular. You have probably stumbled upon some vague sentences on facebook as : “ some people don’t deserve our attention”, “I should have learn not to trust everyone”. But while some manipulators get lost in personal intrigue others thrive in business. These are slightly different as they embrace their manipulation techniques. They face their cognitive dissonance by describing everything as a game, and any behaviour is acceptable as part of the rules. Lying, failing to pay or to keep a promise, intrigues, bullying or exploiting someone in despair is all part of the game. There are actually a few famous books on how to be a total jerk. The most famous one is “Rich Dad. Poor Dad”. It’s written as a self-help book, and throws a few ideas about investment, but is mostly just a manual about not having ethics. It actually says you should make ridiculous offers, and those who take it serious are failing to understand that it’s just a game. The name of the book refers to the main character ignoring his very intelligent and responsible dead who never made a fortune, to follow an uneducated millionaire who takes joy in exploring and tricking his employees and everyone around him. This book should be enough to answer your question, as it describes how smart people are constantly manipulated by those who are less smart but much more manipulative. Another book on this topic is “48 laws of power”, which just describes 48 ways of manipulating others for personal gain. The author calls it “laws” to give the feeling that it’s the only way to go about it. To pretend that honesty and transparency are not an option, being a jerk is just a consequence of nature. You will never find a manipulative technique that requires any intelligence whatsoever.

Manipulation is a skill just like software development is a skill. It's a science and an art at the same time. It's the science of understanding human behaviour and involves controlling perceptions. I.e. you know what you want the person to think so you lead them towards that by controlling their thinking. It's a learned behaviour. It's what marketers do. Being misleading, dishonest, generally corrupt, and knowing who to weed out are part of the toolkit. That's how organizations are built. That's how Steve Jobs got kicked out of his own business. Manipulation doesn't spring from good character. But then again you don't need good character to climb whichever ladder you are climbing. You need skills that will help you reach your power and popularity goals. Manipulation is one of em. Is that smart? if that's what smart means to you, then sure. Some people may have moral and ethical concerns with it and may have a difficult time sleeping at night. But then again, you don't need morality to climb up whichever ladder you are climbing. You need skills that will get you through. Your own brand and image is way more important than the clown working on your team. I've been around manipulators and my observation is that they: - Talk a lot, like a lot. And often about other people, their work, their personal life etc.- Like to be everywhere, all kinds of groups, love to socialize and connect so they can build their *power network*- Endlessly talk about what they've done, doesn't have to be world class.- Love to impose authority whenever possible and often times forcefully, like goons.- Will steal ideas and take credit for it. I personally don't consider these people worthy of respect. Manipulation has deep roots in insecurity. It can help reach goals and so some are ok with being manipulative. Manipulative behaviour can be hard to see. It will appear normal. It really takes a sharp eye and observation to catch it. Once you catch it, cleanse yourself from the company of these people. They are grossly toxic.

Manipulation - Let’s see what it is first. Manipulation, usually mentioned, is doing something because someone else had convinced you to do it, which benefits him/her (*notice there is no phrase “but not you”) Manipulation is done by someone to achieve their ends. And they use the common phrase “the ends justify the means” to justify what they have done. Are manipulative people smart? Not necessarily. They have enough experience and skill to connect the dots to make you do something that you might not have done earlier if they didn’t manipulate you to do so. Let me illustrate : Watch these 2 sentences carefully. If you liked what I have written, please hit the like button or follow my blog (website)If you liked this, you will definitely like this awesome other post I have written. Check it out and if you like it, follow my blog (website)What would you choose if this was there on the site you were reading? You’d most probably choose option 2, right. Why? Because he’s giving you more than what you’ve got. Look at it in a different way. He’s convincing you to make a decision that is in his favor rather than what you’d have done. This is kind of a manipulation. It is done in his favor. These are harmless manipulations. If the article is good, you’d feel that he had influenced you. That is the small difference between those two words. The after taste. Manipulation makes you feel bad about yourself, but influence makes you feel good. Coming back to the question. Manipulators are smart, skilled people. Probably, the definition of smartness might not apply to them. But they have an idea of what to do to make you do something that they want. It might be in their favor or not. They know which switches to push on your remote control. That’s why they are smart.

For example, when soldiers walk in marshes to attack or sniper someone, they can manipulate their enemy to think that they are not there by the clothing they wear, the twigs on their bodies, etc. that make them look that a bush from far away. If a magician wants to perform a disappear trick, they will need to do it real quick plus diverting the audiences’ attention. Same goes for pickpockets. Pickpockets know that if someone is not looking, they can take something because you don’t feel it and that the things out of our viewpoint become invisible. If you consider skill at manipulation to be a form of intelligence, then the question answers itself. Those who don’t consider adeptness at manipulation to be a form of intelligence might be enforcing their own emotional biases. Being able to manipulate others requires a certain degree of social intelligence at the very least. It also requires a clear understanding of cause and effect within the very complex sphere of social behavior. Manipulative behaviors may call upon a high level of skill in communication, acting, deception, subversion, fabrication, etc., depending on the specifics of the given situation. Those activities all call for a high level of intelligence to pull off successfully. So yes, I’d say that being manipulative is itself a form of being smart (assuming that by “manipulative people,” you mean “people who are good at manipulation” and not “people who attempt to engage in manipulation regardless of whether or not they’re any good at it”.). I’m not saying anything of whether it is moral or productive to be manipulative, because that’s not what’s being asked here.
